packageMeta.name: purescript-quaternions
packageMeta.description: A small library providing a Quaternion data type, as well as quaternion-based 3D rotations.

declarations.comments:
A Quaternion. The type parameter denotes the underlying type. Note that
the underlying type should be a reasonable approximation of the real
numbers; if this is not the case, some of the functions may exhibit
strange behaviour.

Note that quaternion multiplication is not commutative; that is, p * q
is usually not the same as q * p. Because of this, there is no Num
Quaternion instance.

The ModuloSemiring instance implements left division; if you need to be
explicit, both types of division are also provided as separate named
functions.
declarations.title: Quaternion

declarations.comments:
The conjugate of a quaternion. This operation negates the vector part of
the quaternion.
declarations.title: conjugate

declarations.comments:
The conjugate of a quaternion by another quaternion. Defined as
`conjBy p q = q * p * recip q`.
declarations.title: conjugateBy

declarations.comments:
The square of the norm of a quaternion. This is slightly easier to compute
than the actual norm, so may be useful in cases where you are worried
about performance.
declarations.title: normSquare

declarations.comments:
Gives a unit quaternion; multiplying this by the quaternion's norm will
give you back the original quaternion.
declarations.title: versor

declarations.comments:
The reciprocal of a quaternion. Multiplying a quaternion by its reciprocal
yields 1.
declarations.title: recip

declarations.comments: Left division; defined as `leftDiv p q = p * recip q`.
declarations.title: leftDiv

declarations.comments: Right division; defined as `rightDiv p q = recip q * p`.
declarations.title: rightDiv

declarations.comments:
Approximate equality of quaternions, given an epsilon value specifying the
maximum amount that any of the four components is allowed to differ by.
declarations.title: approxEq

modules.name: Data.Quaternion.Rotation
modules.comments:
This module provides rotations in 3D space based on quaternions. It is
intended to be imported qualified, for example like this:

    import Data.Quaternion.Rotation (Rotation)
    import Data.Quaternion.Rotation as Rotation

declarations.comments:
A rotation in three-dimensional space, represented by a unit quaternion
(also known as a versor).

The constructor is not exported to ensure that only valid rotations can
be constructed.

The semigroup instance provides composition of rotations; `p <> q` gives
a rotation representating the rotation `q` followed by the rotation `p`.
Note that in general, this is not the same as `p` followed by `q`!
declarations.title: Rotation

declarations.comments: Construct a Rotation from any Quaternion, by normalizing to a versor.
declarations.title: fromQuaternion

declarations.comments:
Construct a `Rotation` representing the rotation by the specified angle
(in radians) about the specified axis. The rotation is clockwise from the
point of view of someone looking along the direction of the rotation axis.
declarations.title: fromAngleAxis

declarations.comments:
Gives the angle and axis that a rotation represents. This is the inverse
of `fromAngleAxis`.
declarations.title: toAngleAxis

declarations.comments: An alternative string representation, which can be useful for debugging.
declarations.title: showAngleAxis

declarations.comments:
The inverse of a rotation. The following should hold for any rotation `p`:

* `inverse p <> p == mempty`
* `p <> inverse p == mempty`
declarations.title: inverse

declarations.comments:
The action of a rotation on a vector in 3D space. This is a group action,
which means that the following hold:

* Identity: `act mempty == id`
* Compatibility: `act p (act q v) = act (p <> q) v`
declarations.title: act
